<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>40:50</designator>
<name>Advertising to minors prohibited</name>
</outline.name.block>
<online.view>
<online.view.item>FMS</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>LGV</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>ORD</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>FCV</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>FTR</online.view.item>
</online.view>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<form uuid="I441fbf602f4f11e3947f0000837bc6dd">
<form.unit>
<form.para>
<form.text>Section 1.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Legislative intent.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>A</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>The Common Council finds that certain tobacco product manufacturers have admitted engaging in strategies designed to advertise and promote tobacco products to minors and that such strategies undermine state laws prohibiting the sale or distribution of tobacco products to minors. The Common Council further finds that the exposure of minors to such tobacco product advertising and promotion may be constitutionally restricted through the enactment of reasonable targeted limitations on the advertising and promotion of such products near schools and other like locations regularly frequented by children so as to strengthen compliance with and enforcement of laws prohibiting the sale or distribution of tobacco products to children and protect children against such illegal sales.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.unit>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>(1)</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Although the rate of smoking among adults nationwide has decreased by 50% between 1971 and 1993, the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have reported that the rate of smoking among all high school students during the years 1991 through 1996 increased by over 26% and now stands at its highest rate since 1981. This dramatic increase in teenage smoking has occurred while all 50 states and the District of Columbia have had prohibitions in effect on the sale or distribution of cigarettes and other tobacco products to minors and while all tobacco product manufacturers were pledged to adhere to a voluntary industry code prohibiting advertisement of tobacco products that appeal to or influence minors. In <inline.instr>__lsqb__name of state__rsqb__</inline.instr> State it is illegal to sell tobacco products to a minor.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>(2)</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>It has also been reported that nearly 90% of all smokers begin to smoke prior to the age of 18, and the average child smoker starts daily smoking by the age of 14. Between 1991 and 1996 the rate of smoking among Hispanic high school students nationwide reportedly increased by over 34% while, during the same period, the rate of smoking among African-American high school students nationwide increased by over 48%; these rates of increased smoking are the highest in a decade.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>(3)</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Similarly, a 1994 report by the United States Surgeon General containing data on the use of smokeless tobacco by minors reported that the market for smokeless tobacco had shifted dramatically toward young people since 1970. That report cited school-based surveys conducted in 1991 which estimated that 19.2% of ninth to 12th grade boys use smokeless tobacco. Among high school seniors who had ever tried smokeless tobacco, the report said, 73% did so by the ninth grade.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>(4)</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Recently surveys find that there has been a significant increase in cigar smoking by minors. In <inline.instr>__lsqb__name of county__rsqb__</inline.instr>, <inline.instr>__lsqb__name of state__rsqb__</inline.instr>, 12.7% of ninth-grade students reported smoking a cigar during the previous 30 days. National data indicates that more than 27% of 14 to 19 year-olds had smoked a cigar.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>(5)</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>The Easy Access report cited a 1992 Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA) article entitled “Brand Logo Recognition by Children Aged 3 to 6 Years” which demonstrated that 30% of the three-year-olds and 91% of the six-year-olds surveyed could correctly match the Joe Camel cartoon trademark with Camel cigarettes; and a 1991 JAMA report entitled “RJR Nabisco's Cartoon Camel Promotes Camel Cigarettes to Children” which estimated that illegal sales of Camel cigarettes to minors rose from six million dollars per year before the advent of Joe Camel in 1988 to $476 million by the end of 1991. The 1991 JAMA report concluded that one-fourth of all Camel sales in 1991 were to minors.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>(6)</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>A 1991 JAMA study concluded that “cigarette advertising encourages youth to smoke and should be banned.” In a 1994 report, the National Institute of Medicine stated that “the substantial convergent evidence that advertising and promotion increase tobacco use by youths is impressive and, in the Committee's view, provides a strong basis for legal regulation.” Similarly, a 1995 report by the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention found that “cigarette marketing practices appeared to be the most likely to account for the increase in teen smoking initiation rates.”</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>(7)</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>The federal Department of Health and Human Services' Food and Drug Administration (FDA) recently reported that:</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>(8)</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>In announcing its final rules on the advertising and promotion of tobacco products, published in the Federal Register on August 28, 1996, the FDA commented upon the nexus between advertising and proration and smoking among minors. The FDA observed that the images typically associated with advertising and promotion convey the message that tobacco use is a desirable, socially approved, safe and healthful, and widely practiced behavior among young adults, whom children and youths want to emulate. As a result, tobacco advertising and promotion undoubtedly contribute to the multiple and convergent psychosocial influences that lead children and youths to begin using these products and become addicted to them.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>(9)</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>In that same announcement on its final rules on advertising and promotion of tobacco products, the FDA discussed the issue of federal preemption of state and local restrictions. The FDA specifically stated that:</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>(10)</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>On March 20, 1997, as part of a settlement agreement signed by the Attorneys General of 17 states, including <inline.instr>__lsqb__name of state__rsqb__</inline.instr>, and Liggett &amp; Myers Inc. and the Brooke Group, Ltd., cigarette manufacturers, the following statement was among those made by and on behalf of Liggett &amp; Myers: “Liggett acknowledges that the tobacco industry markets to &lsquo;‘youth&rsquo;’, which means those under 18 years of age....”</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
</form.unit>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>B</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>In light of the foregoing evidence that cigarettes are advertised and promoted to minors and that smoking by minors continues to dramatically increase despite laws banning the sale or distribution of tobacco products to minors, the Common Council finds and declares that affirmative, reasonable and constitutionally permissible restrictions on tobacco product advertising and promotion may and must be enacted.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>C</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>The purpose of this chapter is to promote enforcement of the aforementioned laws banning the sale or distribution of tobacco products to minors and to protect young people. The Common Council is cognizant of the necessity of acting within the protection afforded by the <st>First Amendment to the United States Constitution</st> and has, therefore, narrowly tailored the scope and effect of this legislation to impose reasonable time, place and manner restrictions on tobacco advertising aimed at or regularly seen by youth while not directly affecting advertising directed at adults.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.para>
<form.text>Section 2.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Definitions.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>As used in this chapter the following terms shall have the meanings indicated:</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>CHILD DAY-CARE CENTER</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>A</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Any public, private or parochial child-care center, school-age child-care program, day nursery school, kindergarten, play school or other similar school or service.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>B</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Any day-care center or day-care home as defined by <inline.instr>__lsqb__citation of reference__rsqb__</inline.instr> of the Code of the City of <inline.instr>__lsqb__name of city__rsqb__</inline.instr>.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>C</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Any facility that provides child-care services as defined in <inline.instr>__lsqb__reference of statutory code__rsqb__</inline.instr> of the <inline.instr>__lsqb__name of state__rsqb__</inline.instr> State Social Services Law.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>D</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>“Child day-care center” shall not include child day-care centers located in private residences and multiple dwelling units.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>CHILDREN'S INSTITUTION</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>A</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Any public, private or parochial congregate institution, group residence, group home or other place where, for compensation or otherwise, seven or more children under three years of age are received for day and night care apart from their parents or guardians.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>B</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Youth center or facilities for detention as defined in <inline.instr>__lsqb__citation of reference__rsqb__</inline.instr> of the <inline.instr>__lsqb__name of state__rsqb__</inline.instr> State Executive Law.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>C</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Group homes for children as defined in <inline.instr>__lsqb__citation of reference__rsqb__</inline.instr> of the <inline.instr>__lsqb__name of state__rsqb__</inline.instr> State Social Services Law.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>D</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Public institutions for children as defined in <inline.instr>__lsqb__citation of reference__rsqb__</inline.instr> of the <inline.instr>__lsqb__name of state__rsqb__</inline.instr> State Social Services Law.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>E</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Residential treatment facilities for children and youth as defined in Section <inline.instr>__lsqb__citation of reference__rsqb__</inline.instr> of the <inline.instr>__lsqb__name of state__rsqb__</inline.instr> State Mental Hygiene Law. The term “children's institution” shall not include children's institutions located in private residences and multiple dwelling units.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>PERSON&mdash;Any natural person, partnership, corporation, government agency, association or other legal entity.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>PLAYGROUND&mdash;An outdoor area open to the public where children play, which contains play equipment such as a sliding board, swing, jungle gym, sandbox, play platform or which is designated as a public play area or which includes but is not limited to a baseball diamond or basketball courts.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>PRIVATE RESIDENCE&mdash;Any building or structure designed and occupied for residential purposes by not more than two families, including the grounds of such building or structure.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>PUBLICLY VISIBLE LOCATION</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>A</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Any outdoor location visible to the public, including but not limited to outdoor billboards, roofs and sides of buildings, water towers and freestanding signboards.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>B</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Any doors or windows reasonably visible to the public from the outside at a distance of two feet from such doors or windows.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>C</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>“Publicly visible location” shall not include any location intended to be visible only by those inside a premises, or a private residence or any door or window of a multiple dwelling unit.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>SCHOOL PREMISES&mdash;The buildings, grounds or facilities, or any portion thereof, owned, occupied by or under the custody or control of public, private or parochial institutions for the primary purpose of providing educational instruction to students at or below the 12th-grade level.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>SMOKELESS TOBACCO&mdash;Any product that consists of cut, ground, powdered or leaf tobacco that is intended to be placed in the oral cavity.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>TOBACCO ADVERTISEMENT&mdash;Any words, pictures, posters, placards, signs, photographs, symbols, devices, graphic displays or visual images of any kind, or any combination thereof, the purpose or effect of which is to promote the use or sale of a tobacco product including through the identification of a brand of a tobacco product, a trademark of a tobacco product or trade name associated exclusively with a tobacco product.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>TOBACCO PRODUCT&mdash;Cigarettes, cigars, smokeless tobacco and cigarette tobacco.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>TOBACCO PRODUCT PROMOTION</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>A</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>The marketing, licensing, sale or distribution of items or services, or causing items or services to be marketed, licensed, sold or distributed, whether indoors or outdoors, which are not tobacco products but which bear the brand name, alone or in conjunction with any work, logo, symbol, motto, selling, message, recognizable color or pattern or colors, or any other indicia or product identification identical or similar to, or identifiable with, or those used for any brand of tobacco product; or</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>B</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Offering or causing to be offered any gift or item other than a tobacco product to any person purchasing a tobacco product in consideration of the purchase thereof, or to any person in consideration of furnishing evidence, such as credits, proofs-of-purchase or coupons, of such purchase; provided, however, that a tobacco product promotion shall not include the exchange or redemption through the mail of any such credits, proofs-of-purchase coupons or other evidence of the purchase of a tobacco product.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>YOUTH CENTER&mdash;Any designated indoor public, private or parochial facility, other than a private residence or a multiple dwelling unit, which contains programs that regularly provide activities or services for persons who have not yet reached the age of 18 years, including but not limited to community-based programs, after-school programs, weekend programs, violence prevention programs, leadership development programs, vocational programs, substance abuse prevention programs, individual or group counseling, case management, remedial, tutorial or other educational assistance or enrichment, music, art, dance and other recreational or cultural activities, physical fitness activities and sports programs.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.para>
<form.text>Section 3.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Tobacco advertisement restriction.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>A</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>It shall be unlawful for any person to place, cause to be placed or to maintain a tobacco advertisement in any publicly visible location on or within 1,000 feet of the perimeter of any of the following:</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.unit>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>(1)</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>school premises;</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>(2)</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>a playground or playground area in a public park;</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>(3)</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>a child day-care center;</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>(4)</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>a children's institution;</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>(5)</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>a game room; or</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>(6)</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>a youth center.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
</form.unit>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>B</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>A single sign poster, placard or label no larger than six square feet and containing only black text on a white background may be placed or maintained within 10 feet of an entrance to a commercial establishment where tobacco products are sold or offered for sale.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>C</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>The format of any tobacco advertisements which are placed or maintained in a publicly visible location and which are not subject to the requirements of subsection A or B of this section shall be black text on white background.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.para>
<form.text>Section 4.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Noncompliant advertisements to be removed.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>The owner, operator or lessee of any location or premises where a tobacco advertisement is prohibited or restricted pursuant to Section 3 of this chapter shall remove any noncompliant tobacco advertisement within 30 days from the effective date of this chapter.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para>
<form.text>Section 5.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Tobacco product promotion restricted.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a tobacco product promotion on or within 1,000 feet of the perimeter of any school premises, playground, child day-care center, children's institution, youth center or game room.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para>
<form.text>Section 6.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Noncompliant tobacco product promotion to cease.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>The owner, operator or lessee of any location or premises where a tobacco product promotion is being conducted is prohibited or restricted pursuant to Section 5 of this chapter shall cease any noncompliant tobacco product promotion within 30 days from the effective date of this chapter.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para>
<form.text>Section 7.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Enforcement.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>The <inline.instr>__lsqb__name of city__rsqb__</inline.instr> Police Department shall enforce the provisions of this chapter.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para>
<form.text>Section 8.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Violations; penalties for offenses.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>A</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Any person found to be in violation of this chapter shall be liable for civil penalty of not more than $<inline.instr>__lsqb__dollar amount of fine__rsqb__</inline.instr> for the first violation, not more than $<inline.instr>__lsqb__dollar amount of fine__rsqb__</inline.instr> for the second violation within a two-year period, and not more than $<inline.instr>__lsqb__dollar amount of fine__rsqb__</inline.instr> for the third and each subsequent violation within a two-year period.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>B</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Upon a finding of a violation of this chapter, the court shall direct the removal of the tobacco advertisement and or the cessation of the tobacco product promotion giving rise to the violation.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.para>
<form.text>Section 9.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>Severability.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|68|40:50">
<form.text>If any provision of this chapter shall be adjudged by any court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid, such judgment shall not affect, impair or invalidate the remainder thereof, but shall confine in its operation to the clause, sentence, paragraph, section or part thereof directly involved in the controversy in which such judgment shall have been rendered.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.unit>

<name>Public advertising of cigarettes prohibited</name>
</outline.name.block>
<online.view>
<online.view.item>FMS</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>LGV</online.view.item>
<online.view.item>ORD</online.view.item>

</section.front>
<section.body>
<form uuid="I4422a5902f4f11e3947f0000837bc6dd">
<form.unit>
<form.para>
<form.text>ADVERTISING CIGARETTES PREAMBLE</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>WHEREAS, Section <inline.instr>__lsqb__number of section__rsqb__</inline.instr> of the <inline.instr>__lsqb__citation of reference__rsqb__</inline.instr> Code makes it unlawful for any person engaged in the manufacture or sale of cigarettes to sell, barter or give cigarettes to any individual under the age of 18 years; and</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>WHEREAS, More than three million minors under the age of 18 consume more than 947 million packs of cigarettes annually in the United States, yielding gross sales to the tobacco industry each year of approximately $1 billion; and</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>WHEREAS, Cigarettes are the most heavily advertised product in America, and the tobacco industry spends more than $421 million annually for outdoor advertising of cigarettes; and</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>WHEREAS, Outdoor advertisements are a unique and distinguishable medium of advertising which subjects the general public to involuntary and unavoidable forms of solicitation; and</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>WHEREAS, The Supreme Court and other courts have recognized the positive relationship between advertising and consumption as regards a variety of goods and services, such as electricity, gambling, cigarettes, and alcohol; and</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>WHEREAS, In addition to judicial recognition of the general link between advertising and consumption, there is specific and convincing evidence that tobacco advertising plays a significant role in stimulating illegal consumption of cigarettes by minors, including:</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>pl.ref.id="I0079OT"><field>pl.reftext="Davis R. Current Trends in Cigarette Advertising and Marketing"</field>Davis R. “Current Trends in Cigarette Advertising and Marketing,” New England Journal of Medicine. 1987; 316:725&ndash;-732.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>pl.ref.id="I0079OV"><field>pl.reftext="Chapman S., Fitzgerald B. Brand Preference and Advertising Recall in Adolescent Smokers: Some Implications for Health Promotion"</field>Chapman S., Fitzgerald B. “Brand Preference and Advertising Recall in Adolescent Smokers: Some Implications for Health Promotion,” American Journal of Public Health. 1982; 72:491&ndash;-494.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>pl.ref.id="I00A2TR"><field>pl.reftext="Klintzner M., Gruenewald PJ, Bamberger E. Cigarette Advertising and Adolescent Experimentation with Smoking"</field>Klintzner M., Gruenewald PJ, Bamberger E. “Cigarette Advertising and Adolescent Experimentation with Smoking,” British Journal of Addiction. 1991; 86:287&ndash;-298.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>pl.ref.id="I0079UJ"><field>pl.reftext="Goldstein A.O., Fischer P.M., Richards J.W., Cretin B.A. Relationship Between High School Student Smoking and Recognition of Cigarette Advertisements"</field>Goldstein A.O., Fischer P.M., Richards J.W., Cretin B.A. “Relationship Between High School Student Smoking and Recognition of Cigarette Advertisements,” Journal of Pediatrics. 1987; 110:488&ndash;-491.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>pl.ref.id="I00A2ZF"><field>pl.reftext="Hunter S.M., Webber L.S., Berenson G.S. Cigarette Smoking and Tobacco Usage Behavior in Children and Adolescents: Bogalusa Heart Study"</field>Hunter S.M., Webber L.S., Berenson G.S. “Cigarette Smoking and Tobacco Usage Behavior in Children and Adolescents: Bogalusa Heart Study,” Preventive Medicine. 1980; 9:701&ndash;-712.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>pl.ref.id="I0079UL"><field>pl.reftext="Hunter S.M., Croft J.B., Burke G.L., Parker F.C., Webber L.S., Berenson G.S. Longitudinal Patterns of Cigarette Smoking and Smokeless Tobacco Use in Youth: the Bogalusa Heart Study"</field>Hunter S.M., Croft J.B., Burke G.L., Parker F.C., Webber L.S., Berenson G.S. “Longitudinal Patterns of Cigarette Smoking and Smokeless Tobacco Use in Youth: the Bogalusa Heart Study,” American Journal of Public Health. 1986; 76:193&ndash;-195.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>pl.ref.id="I00A2ZH"><field>pl.reftext="Aitken P.P., Leathar D.S., O'Hagan F.J., Squair S.I. Children's Awareness of Cigarette Advertising and Brand Imagery"</field>Aitken P.P., Leathar D.S., O'Hagan F.J., Squair S.I. “Children's Awareness of Cigarette Advertising and Brand Imagery,” British Journal of Addiction. 1987; 82:615&ndash;-622.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>pl.ref.id="I00CW4D"><field>pl.reftext="Charlton A. Children's Advertisement Awareness Related to Their Views of Smoking"</field>Charlton A. “Children's Advertisement Awareness Related to Their Views of Smoking,” Health Education Journal. 1986; 45(2)75&ndash;-78.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>pl.ref.id="I0079UN"><field>pl.reftext="Aitken P.P., Leathar D.S., Squair S.I. Children's Awareness of Cigarette Brand Sponsorship of Sports and Games in the UK"</field>Aitken P.P., Leathar D.S., Squair S.I. “Children's Awareness of Cigarette Brand Sponsorship of Sports and Games in the UK,” Health Education Research. 1987; 1:203&ndash;-211.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>pl.ref.id="I00A2ZJ"><field>pl.reftext="Alexander H.M., Calcott R., Dobson A.J., et al. Cigarette Smoking and Drug Use in School Children, IV: Factors Associated with Changes in Smoking Behavior"</field>Alexander H.M., Calcott R., Dobson A.J., et al. “Cigarette Smoking and Drug Use in School Children, IV: Factors Associated with Changes in Smoking Behavior,” International Journal of Epidemiology. 1983; 12:59&ndash;-66.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>WHEREAS, The 1992 <inline.instr>__lsqb__statement of matter__rsqb__</inline.instr> Adolescent Drug Survey conducted by the <inline.instr>__lsqb__statement of matter__rsqb__</inline.instr> Department of Education found that:</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.item>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>Cigarettes are the second most commonly used substance by <inline.instr>__lsqb__number of adolescents__rsqb__</inline.instr> adolescents, with 41.9% of 12th graders and 11.2% of sixth graders having used cigarettes in the 12 months preceding the study.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>Cigarettes constitute a “gateway drug” among <inline.instr>__lsqb__number of students__rsqb__</inline.instr> students, i.e., a substance which is used by adolescents as a first drug and opens the door for use of other “harder” substances at a later date.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>75% of 12th graders first tried cigarettes before the age of 15.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>By age 10 or under, 12.4% of males and 9.3% of females smoke.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>Roughly 14% of 12th graders smoke on a daily basis.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>The percentage of <inline.instr>__lsqb__number of students__rsqb__</inline.instr> students using cigarettes in the 12 months preceding the survey exceeds the national percentage by 13.6% for 12th graders, 15% for 10th graders, and 12.1% for eighth graders.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>Cigarette users were more likely than users of other substances described in the Survey to report having tried unsuccessfully to stop.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>Cigarette use by sixth graders appears to be increasing with the percentage of sixth graders reporting having used cigarettes in the past 30 days increasing from 3.6% in 1988 to 4.7% in 1992.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>4.7% of sixth graders, 14.4% of eighth graders, 22.7% of 10th graders, and 31.5% of 12th graders reported use of cigarettes within the past 30 days.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>Cigarettes are a “gateway” drug among <inline.instr>__lsqb__number of students__rsqb__</inline.instr> students, i.e., a substance often used by adolescents as a first drug which appears to “open the door” for use of harder drugs at a later date; and</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>WHEREAS, An ordinance restricting the placement of advertisements for cigarettes in publicly visible locations within City of <inline.instr>__lsqb__name of city__rsqb__</inline.instr> is a reasonable and necessary measure for reducing illegal consumption of cigarettes by minors; and</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>WHEREAS, The restrictions contained in the following Ordinance will not unduly burden legitimate business activities of persons licensed by the State of <inline.instr>__lsqb__name of state__rsqb__</inline.instr> to sell cigarettes on a retail basis; and</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>WHEREAS, In order to protect legitimate business activities and to narrowly focus its efforts on those advertisements which most directly affect minors where they live, attend school, attend church and engage in recreational activities, the City of <inline.instr>__lsqb__name of city__rsqb__</inline.instr> Council has determined not to restrict advertisements of cigarettes in certain designated business and industrial zones hereinafter identified, with reasonable and appropriate setbacks from adjoining zones.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.para>
<form.text>Section 1 Cigarette advertisements.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>No person may place any sign, poster, placard, device, graphic display, or other form of advertising that advertises cigarettes in a publicly visible location. In this section “publicly visible location” includes outdoor billboards, sides of building, and freestanding signboards. This section shall not apply to:</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.item>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>The placement of signs, including advertisements: (i) inside any premises used by a holder of a cigarette business “license” as defined in Section <inline.instr>__lsqb__number of section__rsqb__</inline.instr> of the Business Regulation article of the <inline.instr>__lsqb__citation of reference__rsqb__</inline.instr> code; or (ii) on commercial vehicles used for transporting cigarettes;</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>Any sign that contains the name or slogan of the premises used by a holder of a cigarette business license that has been placed for the purpose of identifying such premises;</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>Except for billboards and freestanding signboards, any sign for which zoning board approval or a minor privilege permit is require;</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>Any sign that contains a generic description of cigarettes;</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>Any neon or electrically charged sign on premises used by a holder of a cigarette business license that is provided as part of a promotion of a particular brand of cigarettes;</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>Any sign on an Transit Authority vehicle or a taxicab;</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>Any sign on property owned, leased or operated by the <inline.instr>__lsqb__name of authority__rsqb__</inline.instr> stadium authority;</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>Any sign at <inline.instr>__lsqb__name of stadium__rsqb__</inline.instr>;</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>Any sign at a facility that operates in accordance with a license issued under Section <inline.instr>__lsqb__number of section__rsqb__</inline.instr> of the Business Regulation article of the <inline.instr>__lsqb__citation of reference__rsqb__</inline.instr> Code;</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>Any sign on property adjacent to an interstate highway; or</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>Any sign located: (i) in a <inline.instr>__lsqb__designation of zone 1__rsqb__</inline.instr> zone, (ii) in a <inline.instr>__lsqb__designation of zone 2__rsqb__</inline.instr> zone more than 1,000 feet from the boundary of any other zone which is not a <inline.instr>__lsqb__designation of zone 1__rsqb__</inline.instr> or <inline.instr>__lsqb__designation of zone 2__rsqb__</inline.instr> zone, (iii) in a <inline.instr>__lsqb__designation of zone__rsqb__</inline.instr> zone more than 500 feet from the boundary of any other zone which is not a <inline.instr>__lsqb__designation of zone 1__rsqb__</inline.instr> or <inline.instr>__lsqb__designation of zone 2__rsqb__</inline.instr> zone provided such sign faces away from any such other adjoining zone.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.para>
<form.text>Section 2 Penalties for Violation.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|69|40:51">
<form.text>Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects, refuses to comply with, or resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this ordinance shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction in any court of competent jurisdiction, shall be fined not less than $<inline.instr>__lsqb__dollar amount of minimum fine__rsqb__</inline.instr> nor more than $<inline.instr>__lsqb__dollar amount of maximum fine__rsqb__</inline.instr>; any person found guilty of violating the provisions of Section 1 may be fined up to $<inline.instr>__lsqb__dollar amount of maximum fine__rsqb__</inline.instr>. Every such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for every day such violation shall continue after notification thereof.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.unit>

<section>
<section.front>
<outline.name.block>
<label>&sect;</label>
<designator>40:51.20</designator>
<name>Advertising on public transportation</name>
</outline.name.block>
</section.front>
<section.body>
<form uuid="Iab252fa0f2a711e69fb3b8671dee65f4">
<form.unit>
<form.para>
<form.text>SECTION 1.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|70|40:51.20">
<form.text>That the <inline.instr>__lsqb__name of city__rsqb__</inline.instr> Transit Board hereby adopts a policy prohibiting the placement, installation or distribution of tobacco (including cigars, cigarettes, smokeless tobacco or tobacco in any of its forms) or alcoholic beverage advertisements on property owned, operated or maintained by the <inline.instr>__lsqb__name of city__rsqb__</inline.instr> Transit Authority. This Section shall not apply to:</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>(a)</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|70|40:51.20">
<form.text>The placement of signs, including advertisements, used by a person licensed to sell tobacco or alcoholic beverages and acting pursuant to a lease or license with the <inline.instr>__lsqb__name of city__rsqb__</inline.instr> Transit Authority; or</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>(b)</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|70|40:51.20">
<form.text>Any sign that contains the name or slogan of the premises used by a person licensed to sell tobacco or alcoholic beverages and acting pursuant to a lease or license with the <inline.instr>__lsqb__name of city__rsqb__</inline.instr> Transit Authority;</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.item>
<name.block>
<designator>(c)</designator>
</name.block>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|70|40:51.20">
<form.text>Any sign that contains a generic description of tobacco or alcoholic beverages on premises used a person licensed to sell tobacco or alcoholic beverages and acting pursuant to a lease or license with the <inline.instr>__lsqb__name of city__rsqb__</inline.instr> Transit Authority.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.item>
<form.para>
<form.text>SECTION 2.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|70|40:51.20">
<form.text>The Authority shall take whatever steps are necessary to implement this ordinance, including, but not limited to, amending or terminating, consistent with applicable law, existing contracts to conform with the ordinance. No renewals, extensions or new contracts for tobacco or alcoholic beverage advertising will be permitted after the effective date of this ordinance.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para>
<form.text>SECTION 3.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para ct.id="94c763f0b7ba11efb3499aa8422d3018|70|40:51.20">
<form.text>The Authority shall inform all tenants under existing month-to-month leases, licenses or contracts that the terms of this ordinance shall be incorporated in their lease, license or contract beginning no later than the first monthly renewal occurring at least 30 days after receipt of such notice and that violation of this ordinance shall constitute a default under the lease, license or contract.</form.text>
</form.para>
<form.para>
<form.text>SECTION 4.</form.text>
</form.para>
</form.unit>
</para>
